intro: Euthales fructipendula, commonly known as the fruit-bearing eupatorium, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and aromatic foliage. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are typically opposite, lance-shaped, and have a distinctive silvery underside. Euthales fructipendula thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks.
